00039 class ConcurrencyException : public exception {
00040         public:
00041 
00042                 ConcurrencyException ( string message = NULL ): msg ("ConcurrencyException") {
00043                         msg = message ;
00044                 }
00045 
00046                 ConcurrencyException ( char *message ) {
00047                         msg = message ;
00048                 }
00049 
00050                 ~ConcurrencyException () throw (){}; 
00051 
00052 
00053                 virtual inline const char *what () const throw () {
00054                         return msg.c_str () ;
00055                 }
00056 
00057         protected:
00058                 string msg ;
00059 };

00099 
00100 class Condition: public Mutex {
00101 public:
00102   /*
00103   The wait() and wait( int millis )g functions are used to block
00104   on a condition variable. They are called with mutex locked by the calling thread
00105   or undefined behaviour will result. 
00106   These functions atomically release mutex and cause the calling thread to block on
00107   the condition variable cond; atomically here means "atomically with respect to access
00108   by another thread to the mutex and then the condition variable". That is, if another
00109   thread is able to acquire the mutex after the about-to-block thread has released it,
00110   then a subsequent call to pthread_cond_signal() or pthread_cond_broadcast() in that
00111   thread behaves as if it were issued after the about-to-block thread has blocked. 
00112 
00113   Upon successful return, the mutex has been locked and is owned by the calling thread. 
00114 
00115   When using condition variables there is always a boolean predicate involving shared variables
00116   associated with each condition wait that is true if the thread should proceed. Spurious wakeups
00117   from the wait() or wait( int millis )g functions may occur. Since the return
00118   from wait() or wait( int millis )g does not imply anything about the value
00119   of this predicate, the predicate should be re-evaluated upon such return. 
00120 
00121   The effect of using more than one mutex for concurrent wait() or
00122   wait( int millis )g operations on the same condition variable is undefined; that is, a
00123   condition variable becomes bound to a unique mutex when a thread waits on the condition variable,
00124   and this (dynamic) binding ends when the wait returns.
00125   */
00126 //  int wait () ;
00127   int simple_wait();
00128   int wait ( int millis = 0) ;
00129   int waitAndLock ( int millis  = 0 ) ;
00130 
00131   /*
00132   The pthread_cond_signal() call unblocks at least one of the threads that are blocked
00133   on the specified condition variable cond (if any threads are blocked on cond). 
00134   */
00135   int signal ();
00136 
00137   /*
00138   The pthread_cond_broadcast() call unblocks all threads currently blocked on the specified condition variable cond.
00139   */
00140   int broadcast ();
00141 
00142   // properties ------------------------------------------------------------
00143 
00144   // constructor/destructor ------------------------------------------------
00145 
00146   Condition ();
00147   ~Condition();
00148 
00149 private:
00150   pthread_cond_t   cond ;
00151 };
00152 
00153 class ScopedMutex {
00154 /*
00155 This class was designed to encapsulate a mutex and automatically control the lock attribute.
00156 The ScopedMutex lock the associated mutex once we instanciate the class and the lock is automatically unlocked
00157 once the object is destroyed. This allow us to correlate the lock with the scope of the object.
00158 */
00159 private:
00160     Mutex *mutex;
00161 
00162 public:
00163 /*
00164 constructors and destructors. The constructor is forced to only accept a mutex object or any object of a subclass.
00165 */
00166     explicit ScopedMutex(Mutex &m) : mutex(&m) { mutex->lock(); }
00167     ~ScopedMutex() { mutex->unlock(); }
00168 
00169 /*
00170 Desabling the = operator.
00171 */
00172     void operator= (ScopedMutex &);
00173 };

00183     std::queue<T *> msg_list;
00184

00189     Pipe();
00190     ~Pipe();
00191 
00197     void push(T*);
00204     T* pop();
00205 
00211         int size();
00212 
00217         void operator= (Pipe &);
00218 };
